title: How to make a west coast canoe

utterances.translation: He is going to build a canoe.
He looks for cedar in the forest.
A cedar tree that is good, that is perfect.
You find a [good] cedar tree, [and then] step up to the base of it.

utterances.transcript: hiistiʔat n̓an̓aan̓ič̓at, ʔustʔas takqiinuʔat, qʷiicaapiʔitq, ḥiinapi, ƛuɬquu.
utterances.translation: You look [it] over from the ground to the top, [noticing] the way it is facing. It is good if it is leaning [a little].
You always pray to and communicate with the Chief Above.

utterances.transcript: ɬaakɬaak̓ʷat, wikp̓iʕatquu, wik̓atquu ʔuusuqtat, wik̓atquu ʕačuuʔat.
utterances.translation: “May there not be an accident. May there be no wounds.”

utterances.transcript: ɬaakšiƛ, n̓aačiiɬa, čaamaapiqčik ʔuxšiƛ waa, qʷiʔiiʔasʔaqƛii ʔuw̓iiƛ.
utterances.translation: “Please watch over [me] (= hear my prayer) so it [will] fall gently. [Gently it will fall] wherever on the ground it will land.”

utterances.transcript: quʔac̓aqƛ, wikyuuquu quw̓iiƛ suč̓asʔi č̓aapaciiɬmaʕuk ʕiiqʕaƛ, “[huu! huu!]”.
utterances.translation: There is a man inside. Before felling the tree, the canoe make cries “ho! ho!”
You warn the spirit inside the tree.
You want it to leave the tree [that is about to be felled].
The spirit inside [the tree] is [as tall as] from the elbow to the fingertips.
There are two red featheres at the crown of his head.
He flies out from the top [of the tree].

utterances.transcript: č̓aapacmaʕukʔi, wik n̓ačmisinƛ ʔunw̓iiƛ qin č̓iḥʔaqƛ suč̓asʔi.
utterances.translation: The canoe builder is not supposed to look up [when the tree is falling]. Because there is a spirit in the tree.
[This is the] teaching.
Some cedar breaks when it falls onto the ground, having fallen on the ground heavily.
[But] this cedar is soft like a woman.
Then when it falls, place it into the proper position on the ground.
When it lies on the ground properly, look for a measuring stick of the one-fathom length.
Look over the way it is on the ground, examining [it] — “eyeballing [it]” — you could say.

utterances.transcript: kačiʔat ʔuunamaḥsap̓atʔitq č̓apac, qacc̓iiɬ, muuy̓aɬ, suč̓iiɬ, n̓upuuɬ, ʔaƛpuuɬ, ʔaƛakʷaɬ, c̓awaakʷaɬ, ḥayu, ḥayup̓it, hiikʷaɬ, quušcpaamatak sixty feet ḥayup̓itʔat ɬaaḥšiʔat.
utterances.translation: Measure how long you want to have the canoe: three fathoms, four fathoms, five fathoms, six fathoms, seven fathsom, eight, nine, ten, ten times — almost…, maybe a little over sixty feet — ten stretches of the arm.
When it is positioned on the ground, it is sawed to the length it is going to be.
They always put a string and a sstone [as a plumb] at the end of it.

utterances.transcript: t̓iʕaaʔat̓ap̓at hiišcutiɬʔat kačiʔat, ƛiisšiʔat, XXX ḥuuɬ qʷaaʔitq plumb.
utterances.translation: Drop it [the string with the stone] at both ends, get the measurements, and mark [the measurements] — it’s like a plumb.
This is the way it’s done — when you properly position it on the ground.
The axe and adze were used long ago.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaaʔaƛ ʔaḥ, mamaɬn̓i ʔuusatukukʔi mashiin, powersaw ʔuuḥʷʼaɬʔaƛ ƛaḥ, ƛaḥ katḥhakʔi.
utterances.translation: But now, they use the whiteman’s noise-making machine, a powersaw, nowadays.
This is how it is done, when a canoe is made.
There are so many types of canoes.
[There is a type called] _p̓inw̓aɬ_. _p̓inw̓aɬ_ is a big canoe.

utterances.transcript: waa ʔaḥʔaaʔaƛ ʔaqʔištiik, č̓apacsa waaʔat. qacc̓ap̓it ɬaaḥšiʔat ʔuḥʔiš ƛaʔuu
utterances.translation: And [there is] one called ‘a real canoe’. It is about three fathoms and a little more.
And [there is] one that they used to call ‘fur-sealing’ canoe.

utterances.transcript: waa ʔaḥʔaaʔaƛ ʔunaḥʔisʔi č̓apac k̓aakin, k̓aakin waaʔat. k̓aakinʔis.
utterances.translation: And then there is also a small canoe, _k̓aakin_. It’s called _k̓aakin_, or _k̓aakinʔis_.

utterances.transcript: waa huuʔak ʔuyi qiiʔaƛ, qiisasaƛ, qʷiyuyiič ʔuukʷiiɬ ƛ̓icuuɬ.
utterances.translation: And a very long time ago, they once made _ƛ̓icuuɬ_.
It’s a big canoe, [which is] wide and deep.
They used it at the time of the Flood.

utterances.transcript: waa, ʔaḥʔaaʔaƛ ʕasʕasšiƛ̓asaƛitquu. ʕasʕasš waaʔat, ʕaasuk. č̓aaḥč̓aaḥa.
utterances.translation: And then, when you work on a canoe, you say _ʕaʕasš_ (‘doing carpenter’s work’), _ʕaasuk_ (‘working on a canoe’), or _č̓aaḥč̓aaḥa_ (‘cutting with an adze’).
And there is another…

utterances.transcript: waaʔaaḥs qʷaa ʔin ʔuuwaʔat ʔun̓aaḥ ƛuɬquu [tree for the canoe] .
utterances.translation: I talked about how one looks for a good one — tree for the canoe.
Starting from its bow you shape it.

utterances.transcript: čačimḥičiʔaƛquu ƛaaquuɬ, ʔuutaqšiʔaƛ kʷiscaqc̓uuʔi ƛičaaʔi ƛaaquup̓at.
utterances.translation: When you have properly shaped the bow, you begin to work at the opposite end, the stern. You taper it.
You take a good look so that it will not be out of alignment (crooked, veer to one side).
It [canoe] always veers to one side if the keel is not properly set.
It veers strongly to one side.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥ čimcaqs ʔucaḥtakquu, waa qacaqs ʔucaḥtakquu.
utterances.translation: It may veer to the starboard side or to the port side.
This is how you do it.

utterances.transcript: waa č̓aḥšiʔat, č̓aḥšiʔat, hawiɬčaqšiʔaƛquu hiɬpiiʔi čačimḥiʔap̓at.
utterances.translation: Hew out [the surface to remove all bumps]. When finishing the bottom of the canoe, do it properly. (?)
When you have finished [the bottom of the canoe], turn it [the canoe] over on the ground.
Use three or two heavy long levers.
Pry up the heavy vessel.
This heavy one drops [and] turns over.
Then you work on the inside of the vessel: hew out, chop out the inside of the vessel.
Nowadays it is easy. Using a power saw to saw.

utterances.transcript: čitšiƛ̓aaɬ ʔapw̓inqs hiistiƛ. ʔucačiƛ hiɬyin, ʔucačiƛ ƛičaa,
utterances.translation: Saw from the middle of the vessel toward the bow [and then] to the stern.
That’s how you make the canoe.
It may only take one day;

utterances.transcript: ʔuusaaḥi ʔin wikcukʔic̓aƛ [power saw] ʔuuḥʷʼaɬʔat, mamuuk
utterances.translation: because it is so simple using a power saw to work.

utterances.transcript: hiskʷist̓aḥsʔaƛquu. waa hihisupiʔat hisaawuɬ. qacaqs waaquuk čimcaqs.
utterances.translation: When chopping the inside of the vessel, chop out the insides with short strokes: first the port side, then the starboard side.

utterances.transcript: ʔuḥʔaaɬ ʔuušcuk, hiɬyinʔi. qʷaa y̓uuqʷaa ƛičaaʔi. hiɬst̓uuqs waaʔat.
utterances.translation: The bow and the stern are always difficult: these parts are called _hiɬst̓uuqs_ (‘corner parts of a canoe’).
There at the bow of the canoe it gets hard.
it.makes.a.pinging.sound

notes.text: It makes a pinging sound (= sound of hard wood).
[You can tell the hardness of the wood from the sound it makes when knocked.]

utterances.n-4: It makes a pinging sound (= sound of hard wood).
utterances.n-5: [You can tell the hardness of the wood from the sound it makes when knocked.]

utterances.translation: You have to hurry in order to get the right thinness (i.e. the right gauge).
And then when it is finished, the inside of the canoe is all hallowed out.
Then you drill holes, maybe three: you start from the middle of the vessel.

utterances.transcript: ʔunaak̓at kač̓ak. qʷit̓amaḥsakʔitk ʔuuktisʔat ʔunaḥʔitq č̓apac.
utterances.translation: Take a measuring stick and measure however thick you want it to be on the basis of the length of the canoe.
Finish the bottom of the inside.
Take your time (do it carefully).
Don’t do rough work.
Take a plane.

utterances.transcript: qʷaa ʔaḥʔaaƛ hiɬ ʔat̓aquu piḥpiḥšiʔat, hišcaqs. piḥšiʔat.
utterances.translation: Then examine the thickness on both sides of the vessel.
Feel it with the hand [to know whether it is smooth or not].

utterances.transcript: n̓an̓ačpaɬʔatʔaaɬ ʔaqʔištiik, ʔat̓aʔaƛquu hišcaqsʔi. Curves, yaaqʷiɬcimʔatʔitq waaʔat ƛ̓ačii, ƛ̓ačii, waaʔat.
utterances.translation: You check the thickness of the sides of the canoe: ‘curves’ are what I am talking about. It’s called _ƛ̓ačii_.

utterances.transcription: waa ʔaḥkuu, cikimin waaʔat. č̓aḥy̓ak, hiišiisač̓ak. ʕakm̓aɬst̓uqsy̓ak. ʔuč̓ak hiɬyin. qʷaa y̓uuqʷaa ƛičaa.
utterances.translation: and this steel it.is.said adze axe draw.knife tool.for.it at.the.bow thus also stern

notes.text: And this one is called _cikimin_ (‘steel knife’); [this one is] _č̓aḥy̓ak_ (‘D-adze’); _hiishiisač̓ak_ (‘axe’); _ʕakm̓aɬst̓uqsy̓ak_ (‘draw-knife’), which is used for the bow and also the stern.
As GL draws pictures of tools.

utterances.n-4: And this one is called _cikimin_ (‘steel knife’); [this one is] _č̓aḥy̓ak_ (‘D-adze’); _hiishiisač̓ak_ (‘axe’); _ʕakm̓aɬst̓uqsy̓ak_ (‘draw-knife’), which is used for the bow and also the stern.
utterances.n-5: As GL draws pictures of tools.

utterances.translation: Take your time.
When it gets at the right thickness (= when you finish adjusting thickness), [you are done with the shaping of the canoe and the shaped canoe piece] is called _ƛaam̓aqak_.
Now, the piece becomes _ƛaam̓aqak_ (= when the piece gets shaped into a canoe), put braces across (like thwarts) [to widen the canoe].
You are going to take it [the canoe] out of the woods.
Find someone to help you.
About four.
Do it early.
Go out fishing early.
You want to be at home early.
While you are making a canoe, men say funny things, say good things [about the canoe].
When you drag it on the ground out of the woods, they make wisecracks.
You want everything to be proper; don’t rush.

utterances.transcript: čiiḥt̓asʔap̓aƛquu č̓apac. ƛuuɬƛuuɬa. quuḥʷʼaɬ c̓istuup. huuhumt̓asuk.
utterances.translation: When the canoe is dragged out of the woods, do it very slowly, using rope and crosspieces [used as skids] on the trail.
Sometimes [the canoe is dragged] from far [and] deep in the woods (far up the hill).
So, this is how you do it.
When [the canoe] is actually coming out the woods, you do it in the same way.
Don’t drag it on the sand.

utterances.transcript: ʔun̓aaḥʔatquu hatkma qʷaaqḥʔaqƛii čačimḥii wikcukʔis hinačištuƛ hatkma, rollers waaʔatquu.
utterances.translation: If you get the _hatkma_ — ‘rollers’ you could call — properly set, it would be easy to put the canoe into the sea.
Pull it into the water.
Now, you are going to tow it.
Come to the place where you are going to work.

utterances.transcript: heey ʔuuš ʔaaʔaapḥi quuʔas ʔuuwaʔaƛquu č̓aapaciiɬ hupiiʔaq suutiɬ.
utterances.translation: When some kind people find you making a canoe, they will help you.
Now drag the canoe on the beach to the dry land.

utterances.transcript: čuu ʔaḥʔaaʔaƛ ʔaqʔištiik waɬyaqpiʔaƛ haʔuk̓ʷap̓aƛ yaayaaquumtʔitq.
utterances.translation: Then, at home you feed the people who helped you.
Take one or two days off.
Now, it is ready.
[You] first put the canoe on the ground.
Place the canoe, the partly finished canoe, on the ground.
Examine and put the canoe properly on the ground — in the way it should be.
Examine it.

utterances.transcript: qʷiyuyis ʔuukčamaɬčaqḥ [Charlie Jones] . čuu kiḥcaasiʔi. waaʔaƛ̓ats [Charlie Jones] .
utterances.translation: When I was [working] with Charlie Jones, he told me “Now, look with one eye.”
Charlie Jones used to say “Take an eyeball.”

utterances.transcription: ʔunw̓iiʔatʔišʔaaɬ k̓iccaasiʔat č̓apac. ʔin k̓icsaasiʔatʔaaɬ ɬuucsaamiiḥ. ʔuuwaʔaƛ̓atquu yaaqʷiɬʔatʔitq kʷinʔaɬʔat.
utterances.translation: the.reason.why.it.is.always.done look.with.one.eye canoe that look.with.one.eye women when.you.find one.whom you.like

notes.text: The reason that people look at the canoe with one eye [to examine closely] is that you look at women with one eye when you come upon a woman you like.
The way they examine their canoe with one eye is the same as when you look at women when they see women they like.

utterances.n-4: The reason that people look at the canoe with one eye [to examine closely] is that you look at women with one eye when you come upon a woman you like.
utterances.n-5: The way they examine their canoe with one eye is the same as when you look at women when they see women they like.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaaʔaƛquu ƛ̓iixʷaa Charlie, [Charlie Jones] . ḥaw̓iɬukʷit p̓aačiinaʔatḥ.
utterances.translation: He was laughing saying that (lit. This is when he was laughing), Charlie Jones, the former chief of the Pachina people.
And then, when the canoe is put in the proper position on the ground, you hew it out again.
When you have finished, plane it.

utterances.transcript: kačuuʔaaɬ hiɬyin, y̓uuqʷaa. ƛičaa. wiiksinḥap̓at ʔaqʔištiik cikcikmis.
utterances.translation: Take a measurement at the bow, and also at the stern, to prevent it, you know, from rocking.
Now, turn it over (to the upright position).
Then, with the canoe turned over on the ground, you adze it [all over] again.

utterances.transcript: hiišiisač̓ak ʔuupi yuušink qʷaaʔitq ʔaqʔištiik, qay̓aaxʷas,
utterances.translation: An axe is handier and faster than, you know, a D-adze.

utterances.transcript: ʔin k̓atyiikʔis ʔaḥ qay̓aaxʷas ʔaniiyač̓ak ḥuuɬ.
utterances.translation: So the D-adze is only used for the lighter work there.
People used to adze in all sorts of ways.
[One technique is] called _ƛ̓ikuuɬ_ — with the arm raised by the forehead.

utterances.transcript: ʔuušckʷiiʔaaɬ ƛ̓ikuuɬ waaʔat. [Just in line with your forehead.]
utterances.translation: Some used to do it [adzing] with his hand just in line with his forehead.
This is how you do it — hack with the hand by your face.
[You start with the starboard side and then] Do the same for the port.
Some men are good at it.
I was good at both left- and right-handed adzing.
That is how an experienced man is.

utterances.transcript: hišuk wikcukʔis, č̓itkʔis waa. č̓itkʔisʔiš waaʔaƛquu n̓uw̓iiqsakitqs.
utterances.translation: [If you are lucky enough to select the right tree,] Everything is easy — you say, _č̓itkʔis_ (‘wood is soft, easy to cut’). My father used to say, _č̓itkʔisʔiš_ (‘it’s soft’).

utterances.transcript: č̓aapaciiɬʔaƛquu, ɬuucmamatakʔiš waaʔaƛquu, ʔaani ɬatx̣ʷak qʷaa.ʔ
utterances.translation: When he was making a canoe, he used to say, “it’s like a woman; it’s really soft”.
Now, when it is completed, the gunwale is curved down.
Make the bottom of the canoe curve [by chipping the edges].
Make it perfect.
Well, now it is finished.
Take care of thwarts.
Never forget to put in thwarts.

utterances.transcript: one, c̓awaak, ʔaƛa, qacc̓a, waa muuquu. taapʔim. ʔuuktisʔat ʔunaḥʔitq.
utterances.translation: One, two, three, or four thwarts, depending on the size of the canoe.

utterances.transcript: yaqsiikitʔiš č̓apac hiɬḥ Denmark, [forty-two feet] ʔuuna hiikʷaɬ [six feet wide] . ʔunaaʕači.
utterances.translation: The canoe I made in Denmark was forty-two feet long and almost six feet wide.
That one had eight: there were eight thwarts.
It was a large canoe.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥ yaqii č̓apac [twenty-two] ʔuyistimniš ʔaʔim ḥuuɬ [try out] [twenty-two] [Ros Kilde] hiɬḥ.
utterances.translation: There were twenty-two of us in that canoe on the first run, trying out, at Ros Kilde.
It was a big canoe.

utterances.transcript: waa huʔaas ʔaƛpup̓ititqač̓a č̓aapšiƛ, ʔin t̓aatn̓aʔis ʔuḥ ʔayamaḥsa
utterances.translation: We repeated the ride — it might have been seven times, because many children wanted [to ride in the canoe].
That is how we make a canoe.
Put [in] thwarts. There! You have finished putting thwarts [in].
Make the gunwale.
Put the gunwale stripping on.
First you begin with putting on the stripping (braces).
He (Charlie Jones) used to say that it was out of alignment.
“Both sides are out of alignment,” he said, “both sides.”
Im.getting.too.fast

notes.text: I’m going a little too fast [in telling you this story].

utterances.n-4: I’m going a little too fast [in telling you this story].

utterances.transcript: kʷaʔaɬʔaƛquu. kʷaʔaɬʔaƛquu ʔuʔaɬaʔap̓aƛ̓atquu kʷama, prow, ḥuu hiɬyinʔi, kʷama ʔuʔaɬaʔap̓aƛ̓atquu ʔunaak̓at ʔaqʔištiik, tumiis.
utterances.translation: When you put the end piece, when you put the wolf’s head prow there on the bow, you use, you know, ashes.
Apply water every once in a while [when you paste].
Now, even it out.
We axe by looking at the number of soot markings.
Hew out both sides of the canoe.
Do the same thing to the surface again.
Well, if it’s properly done [and the two parts fit really well], they say [that it’s just like] the eyes are closed.
Well you put pitch [on the head piece].
It is perfect.
They you put it [the prow] on [the base of the canoe].
Drill one hole at the bow of the canoe.
Charlie Jones used to call it [the dowel to put into the hole] the “king pin”.
And drill a hole on both sides.
And also drill a hole on the top.
You use cedar.
The white men call it a “dowel”.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaaʔaƛ ʔaqʔištiik. ʔuuqstup̓at, ʔuuḥʷʼaɬ ʔin mamaɬn̓i ƛuuʔakʔi.
utterances.translation: Then you put it in, using the whiteman’s glue.
A long time ago we used pitch when we were making a canoe.
You split the wooden nail (doweling) at the ends.
And then you put the V-wedge in.

utterances.transcript: ʔaḥʔaaʔaƛ ƛačiʔaƛ̓atquu, y̓asšiʔat [V-wedge] ʔi ḥuu hiy̓aqƛ̓i.
utterances.translation: Then when you drive the V-wedge in, [the split end of doweling] spreads apart inside.
The top piece is done in the same way.

utterances.transcript: waa ƛičaaʔi, kʷamaakʔi, ƛicaa y̓uuqʷaaʔap̓atƛa tumiis ʔuuḥʷʼaɬʔat.
utterances.translation: And for the stern part, soot is used there too.
Now, put soot on: paste charcoal repeatedly.
Adze for a long time.
It takes one, two days.
Take your time. Don’t rush.

utterances.transcript: [Take your time.] [Take your time.] waaʔaƛquuč, Charlie. (ƛuuɬƛuuɬaʔi.) wik̓ii ʔaaʔaaʔiša. wik̓ii ʔaaʔaaʔiša.
utterances.translation: “Take your time, take your time; Don’t rush, don’t rush,” Charlie used to say.
Well, [you] start adzing.
When you have attached them [the two end pieces], it is finished.
I.am.going.too.fast it.is.done.so

notes.text: I am going too fast [in telling the story].

utterances.n-4: I am going too fast [in telling the story].

utterances.translation: Put the end pieces on.
Say a prayer. Say a prayer so that it will be perfect.
Don’t ever look for a tree that has fallen to the ground.
That is forbidden.

utterances.transcript: ʔuḥtinʔakquuk č̓apac ʔuw̓asckʷiʔi. waa ʔacyuuquuk yaašmaɬ qʷaaʔapckʷiʔitqʔaaɬ huuʔak wiiqʷiiqy̓aanuʔatwaʔišʔaaɬ.
utterances.translation: If a canoe was made from a fallen tree, then, when you went [out] hunting for furseals, they say that there was always trouble from storms.
Many people didn’t come back.
It is forbidden to make a canoe out of a windfall.
That’s the way it [the teaching] is.
[When] you make a canoe, don’t do it without thinking.
Always examine it [the canoe] closely from the end [of the canoe] when it is finished.
That’s what they did long ago.
Now, you feed them.
There on the bottom of the canoe is called a _sipuus_.
At the bow there is a _sipuus_ and there is another at the stern.
It is something like a keel.
You have to be very careful too.
When you have finished adzing, smooth the surface.
If the stern were crooked, you’d say “_cikcuut_”.
This is how a canoe is made.
That’s it.
I forgot about something.
When it is finished, they always charred the canoe bottom carefully [to harden and smooth the surface].

utterances.transcript: ʕiiqaa ḥuu hiist̓iƛ hiɬyin ƛičaa ʕiiqšiƛ.
utterances.translation: It is charred from the bow to the stern.

utterances.transcript: weey yaxšiƛ. wik ʔinštis yaaxyaaxʷa ʔucaḥtak̓ap, ƛičaa.
utterances.translation: And brush [on the surface]. Put your mind to what you are doing. Brush toward the stern.
If you brush towards the bow, it will disturb the surface.

utterances.transcript: ʔunwiiʔaƛ̓iš č̓apac ʕiiqšiʔat ʔin c̓aaḥačiƛ ḥumiisʔi.
utterances.translation: The reason why it is charred is so that the cedar becomes hard.
Don’t do it for a long time.
Examine it and see [the right moment].

utterances.transcript: hee, huƛhaacač̓at heey huuʔap̓inqsak̓at haa, ƛičaa ʔucačiʔat.
utterances.translation: Well, go back and forth and then do it all over toward the stern.
This is how you make a canoe.
Today white people use sandpaper.
Our people used to use [the skin of the back of] dog fish.

utterances.transcript: qʷaaqʷaaʔitq tin̓uukquu rough waa mamaɬn̓i. sačkaɬ.
utterances.translation: It [the skin of the back of the dog fish] is like a grinding slate — “rough” say the whites. It was coarse.
They used to rub all around on the surface of the canoe.
That is how our people were a long time ago.
They used to use the dogfish, the skin of a dogfish.
They are just like sandpaper.
Some are, you know, rough; some are smoother.
People used to be careful.
They did not do things carelessly (they put their mind to it when they were working).
That’s it.
